intro.projectDescription: This dashboard evaluates how well political institutions – Federal Council, Parliament, and political parties – represent the will of the people in national referendums. Recommendations are compared to the actual voting outcome to derive a numeric representativeness value. Assumption: Voters are well-informed
intro.tooltip: R(V, A) results from comparing A(V) (recommendation) with S(V) (public decision).
intro.formulaExplanation: A(V) is the recommendation of actor A (e.g. Federal Council, Parliament, party) on proposal V, and S(V) is the verdict of the public.

home.diagram1Title: Recommendations by Federal Council/Parliament vs Public Decision

diagram1.descriptionText:
This diagram shows how often the public agrees with the recommendations of the Federal Council and the Parliament.

An agreement means that both the institution and the public voted Yes or No. Otherwise, it is considered a disagreement.

The period can be adjusted using the dropdowns above.

Since January 15, 2009, the Federal Council and Parliament have shared the same voting recommendation. Therefore, from that date onwards, only the Parliament’s recommendation is considered.

diagram2.descriptionText:
This visualization shows how closely party positions align with public voting outcomes.

Each line represents a party. The y-axis shows the percentage of votes where the party's recommendation matched the public decision.

diagram3.descriptionText:
This heatmap shows how often recommendations from political actors aligned with the public's decision – grouped by decade.

The greener a cell, the higher the agreement. Red tones indicate lower agreement.

Hovering over a row displays more details and highlights the line.

diagram4.descriptionText:
This map shows how often the selected actor’s recommendations aligned with public voting outcomes by canton.

The color intensity indicates the level of agreement. Select Federal Council or a party above.
